fields.title: Schema – structuring the content
fields.description: Learn how to structure the content in your project.

children.text: describes the structure of the content. You might also know it as the content model.
. It must start with an uppercase letter and can only contain letters, numbers and underscore, e.g. "Article", "GlossaryTerm".
It's possible to limit an entity type to be
, which means that entities of the type can't be published.
By default, entities can be created with any
. This can be restricted with an
. E.g. to restrict entities to have the authorization key "none", you can create a
The rest of the entity type is defined as
. The way the fields are specified is the same for entity types and value types, so you can read about it below.
, and it has the same naming restrictions.
It's possible to limit a value type to be
. A value item of that type can't be published. It you want to store a value item in an entity that is published, it has to be in an admin only field.
The rest of the value type is defined as
Entity types and value types can contain any number of fields.
, which only needs to be unique within the type. The name has to start with a lowercase letter and can only contain letters, numbers and underscore, e.g. "title", "isOpen".
In order to prevent a field from being empty when it's published, it can be marked as
. You can still save an entity with empty required fields, but in order to publish the entity, all required fields must have a value.
Just as you can make a whole type admin only, you can also specify that just a field should be
. All admin only fields are hidden from the published entity.
In order to know what kind of data can be stored in a field, each field has an associated
(Boolean, Entity, Location, Number, Rich text, String or Value item).
A field can contain a single value, or a
of values. All items in the list must be of the same field type, e.g. a list of String, or a list of Value item.
Some types also comes with more configuration options.
A boolean field can be true, false or not set.
An entity field contains a reference to an entity.
A location field contains latitude and longitude (using the EPSG:4326/WGS 84 coordinate system).
A number field contains any number, either

A rich text field contains text with formatting (e.g. bold, italic) and can contain multiple blocks (e.g paragraph, bullet list) and other content. It can also contain value items and references to entities.
are required for all rich text fields
are needed for bullet, numbered and check lists
is needed for references to entities where the entity is embedded (e.g. an image)
is needed for text linking to an entity (e.g. link to an article)
is needed for text linking to a URL
is needed for embedded value items
there might be more node types that are applicable
that can be embedded in the rich text field. This configuration required
, which is the entity types that can be linked to. This configuration requires
that can be embedded in the rich text field. This configuration required
A string field contains text without any formatting.
string can contain multiple lines of text.
is specified for string field, it's possible to ensure that the value is unique within that index.
It's possible to specify that the value must
A value item field contains a value item.
can be used in the field.

Currently there is only support for one kind of index, a unique index. For fields using the same unique index, there can be only one instance of each value. One use case for unique indexes is slugs, where you want to ensure that a certain link only points to one entity.
. Each pattern must have a unique
Patterns can be used to restrict authorization key values for an entity type, or values in string fields.
